articles.headline: A.I.G. Takes Its Session in Hot Seat
articles.snippet: At a hearing on compensation and spending at A.I.G, one lawmaker criticized the “unbridled greed” of executives.
articles.abstract: At a hearing on compensation and spending at A.I.G, one lawmaker criticized the “unbridled greed” of executives.
articles.lead_paragraph: A day after Richard S. Fuld Jr. was compelled to explain the millions of dollars he made at Lehman Brothers, two former executives of the American International Group took their turns in government witness chairs on Tuesday, answering critical questions from lawmakers about business and pay practices and outsize spending that continued even after the company received an $85 billion lifeline from the government.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced and Sharon Otterman

articles.headline: Two Countries Plan Rescues as European Leaders Continue to Talk
articles.snippet: Britain and Spain moved to mount separate rescues of their financial industries, a move that comes at a time when European economic weakness gives signs of deepening.
articles.abstract: Britain and Spain moved to mount separate rescues of their financial industries, a move that comes at a time when European economic weakness gives signs of deepening.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUXEMBOURG  As European leaders continued to clash over measures to ease the financial crisis, Britain and Spain moved to mount separate rescues of their own financial industries.
articles.byline: By CARTER DOUGHERTY  and LANDON THOMAS

articles.headline: Ignoring Reality Has a Price
articles.snippet: As expensive as the damage control may be, it isn’t likely to cost near as much as the headline numbers suggest.
articles.abstract: As expensive as the damage control may be, it isn’t likely to cost near as much as the headline numbers suggest.

articles.headline: With Bonds in Trouble, States Seek Federal Help
articles.snippet: California and other states scrambled to cope with bills coming due as they pressed Washington for assistance because the municipal bond markets remain largely closed to them.
articles.abstract: California and other states scrambled to cope with bills coming due as they pressed Washington for assistance because the municipal bond markets remain largely closed to them.
articles.lead_paragraph: California and other states scrambled on Tuesday to cope with bills coming due as they pressed Washington for assistance because the municipal bond markets remain largely closed to them.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Randal C. Archibold

articles.headline: Economic Woes Set Tone for Rivals in 2nd Debate
articles.snippet: In a muted debate, Senator Barack Obama faulted a zeal for deregulation, while Senator John McCain offered a mortgage rescue plan.
articles.abstract: In a muted debate, Senator Barack Obama faulted a zeal for deregulation, while Senator John McCain offered a mortgage rescue plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senators John McCain and Barack Obama debated for 90 minutes on Tuesday night before a nation in economic crisis, each promising anxious Americans that he had the better plan and vision to lead the country through what both men said was the most dire financial situation since the Great Depression.

articles.headline: Forget Logic; Fear Appears to Have Edge
articles.snippet: The markets have become a case study in crowd psychology, experts say, as investors seem to be selling first and asking questions later.
articles.abstract: The markets have become a case study in crowd psychology, experts say, as investors seem to be selling first and asking questions later.
articles.lead_paragraph: The technical term for it is “negative feedback loop.” The rest of us just call it a panic.

articles.headline: Downturn in Decibels, Too
articles.snippet: The presidential debate was remarkable for the senators’ subdued demeanors even as they tore into each other.
articles.abstract: The presidential debate was remarkable for the senators’ subdued demeanors even as they tore into each other.
articles.lead_paragraph: Neither candidate was selling morning in America. At times it seemed more like a competition to see who could paint the gloaming in the least unsettling hues.

articles.headline: Retailers’ Sales Fall Sharply at Both High End and Low
articles.snippet: Retail analysts and executives said they had not seen such a rapid slowdown in consumer spending since the nation’s last deep recession, in the early 1980s.
articles.abstract: Retail analysts and executives said they had not seen such a rapid slowdown in consumer spending since the nation’s last deep recession, in the early 1980s.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sales at some of the nation’s best-known retailers fell by double digits in September, highlighting the rapid deterioration of the economy and raising fresh questions about how many of those chains can survive.

articles.headline: U.S. May Take Ownership Stake in Banks
articles.snippet: Treasury officials say the just-passed $700 billion bailout bill gives them the authority to inject cash into banks that request it.
articles.abstract: Treasury officials say the just-passed $700 billion bailout bill gives them the authority to inject cash into banks that request it.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Having tried without success to unlock frozen credit markets, the Treasury Department is considering taking ownership stakes in many United States banks to try to restore confidence in the financial system, according to government officials.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Mark Landler
